customer_addr:

FORT LAUDERDALE, FL 33330

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, an adequate contingency plan, environmental enhancement program for non-human primates,
and Program of Veterinary Care were not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal
Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal
welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are
available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. Correction date: June 30, 2023.

Several of the primate enclosures do not appear to have been thoroughly cleaned recently. The indoor enclosure housing
a ring-tailed lemur contains an excessive accumulation of crushed animal feces, food particles, hair, and organic material
on the enclosure floor, climbing structures, and wire mesh caging.
The holding cage housing a female baboon contained an excessive amount of crushed feces in the bottom of the cage. At
the time of inspection, the baboon was observed pacing back and forth through the feces, soiling her hands and feet.
Not maintaining appropriate levels of cleanliness in areas where non-human primates come in contact can result in an
excessive build-up of materials, which can increase the disease risk for the animals contained within. Per the regulations,
hard surfaces with which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot-cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance
with § 3.84 of this subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards. If the species scent mark, the surfaces
must be sanitized or replaced at regular intervals as determined by the attending veterinarian in accordance with
generally accepted professional and husbandry practices. Correction Date: June 21,2023

Upon entering the facility, an immediate overpowering stench of urine, feces, and ammonia was present. The indoor
enclosure housing two racoons has an excessive accumulation of feces and brown organic material on the enclosure
floor, climbing structures and wire mesh caging. Failure to clean excreta from primary enclosures as often as necessary
can lead to disease and contribute to odors. Additionally, the enclosure contained numerous gel foam pieces scattered
around the enclosure floor. The facility representative stated the gel foam came from a dog bed which the racoons
destroyed. The gel foam could have a negative impact on the health of the raccoons if ingested. The license must ensure
the primary enclosure is cleaned and excreta removed on a routine basis and as often as necessary to minimize disease
hazards and reduce odors. Correction date: June 21, 2023

Housekeeping in the facility needs to be addressed. There are overgrown weeds and vegetation surrounding the puma
and fox outdoor enclosures. Excessively overgrown weeds and vegetation around primary enclosures provide cover and
breeding areas for pests such as rodents which can transmit disease and parasites to the regulated animals. The licensee
must ensure that all premises (buildings and grounds) are kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals
from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices. Correction date: June 30, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, an adequate contingency plan, environmental enhancement program for non-human primates, 
and Program of Veterinary Care were not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal 
Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal 
welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are 
available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. Correction date: June 30, 2023. 
3.75(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Several of the primate enclosures do not appear to have been thoroughly cleaned recently. The indoor enclosure housing 
a ring-tailed lemur contains an excessive accumulation of crushed animal feces, food particles, hair, and organic material 
on the enclosure floor, climbing structures, and wire mesh caging.  
 
The holding cage housing a female baboon contained an excessive amount of crushed feces in the bottom of the cage. At 
the time of inspection, the baboon was observed pacing back and forth through the feces, soiling her hands and feet.  
 
Not maintaining appropriate levels of cleanliness in areas where non-human primates come in contact can result in an 
excessive build-up of materials, which can increase the disease risk for the animals contained within. Per the regulations, 
hard surfaces with which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot-cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance 
with § 3.84 of this subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards. If the species scent mark, the surfaces 
must be sanitized or replaced at regular intervals as determined by the attending veterinarian in accordance with 
generally accepted professional and husbandry practices. Correction Date: June 21,2023 
3.131(a)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
Upon entering the facility, an immediate overpowering stench of urine, feces, and ammonia was present. The indoor 
enclosure housing two racoons has an excessive accumulation of feces and brown organic material on the enclosure 
floor, climbing structures and wire mesh caging. Failure to clean excreta from primary enclosures as often as necessary

can lead to disease and contribute to odors. Additionally, the enclosure contained numerous gel foam pieces scattered 
around the enclosure floor. The facility representative stated the gel foam came from a dog bed which the racoons 
destroyed. The gel foam could have a negative impact on the health of the raccoons if ingested. The license must ensure 
the primary enclosure is cleaned and excreta removed on a routine basis and as often as necessary to minimize disease 
hazards and reduce odors. Correction date: June 21, 2023 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
Housekeeping in the facility needs to be addressed. There are overgrown weeds and vegetation surrounding the puma 
and fox outdoor enclosures. Excessively overgrown weeds and vegetation around primary enclosures provide cover and 
breeding areas for pests such as rodents which can transmit disease and parasites to the regulated animals. The licensee 
must ensure that all premises (buildings and grounds) are kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals 
from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices. Correction date: June 30, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
